headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lisa. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Noble Energy's First Quarter 2010 Earnings Call and Webcast. I'd like to start out with a few introductions. On the call today with me, we have Chuck Davidson, Chairman, CEO; Dave Stover, President, COO; an
componenttext:
Thanks, Lisa. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Noble Energy's First Quarter 2010 Earnings Call and Webcast. I'd like to start out with a few introductions. On the call today with me, we have Chuck Davidson, Chairman, CEO; Dave Stover, President, COO; and Ken Fisher, CFO. Chuck will be making some opening comments here in a few minutes and then we'll discuss the results for the quarter. Dave will then go into our global operations, focusing on our first quarter highlights and the second quarter activity plans. And as usual, we'll leave time for Q&A and wrap up the call in less than an hour. Should you have any questions that we don't get to this morning, please don't hesitate to call and we'll do the best we can to answer you.
We hope everyone has the earnings release in front of them that we issued this morning. It does include some new guidance updates for the second quarter. Later today, we do expect to be filing our 10-Q with the SEC and it will be available on our website.
I want to remind everyone today that the webcast and conference call contains projections and forward-looking statements based on our current views and our most reasonable expectations. We provide no assurances on these statements as a number of factors and uncertainties could cause actual results in the periods to differ materially from what we discuss here today. You should read our full disclosures on forward-looking statements in our latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of the risk factors that influence our business. 
We'll reference certain non-GAAP financial measures here today, such as adjusted net income, or discretionary cash flow. When we refer to these items, it is because we believe they are good metrics to use in evaluating the company's performance. Be sure to see the reconciliations in our earnings release for these items.
With that, let me turn the call over to Chuck.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good morning, everyone. Looking back versus the same time last year, the overall economic outlook has clearly improved and we've seen some dramatic moves in the energy markets. While will be providing an update of our operations in toda
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good morning, everyone. Looking back versus the same time last year, the overall economic outlook has clearly improved and we've seen some dramatic moves in the energy markets. While will be providing an update of our operations in today's call, we plan to go into much greater depth at our Analyst Meeting coming up on June 3, and I hope that you will be able to join us either in person or on the webcast at that time. I think, we'll have many exciting things to share with you at that point.
Now starting out on the pricing side, there continues to be a wide disparity between the market value of crude and natural gas, which on the natural gas side, continues to be challenged from the vast supply that the industry has uncovered, and also the forecast for production growth in 2010. Perhaps last week's break in the gas rig count is an early indicator of producer discipline setting in, but I still have a lot of concerns about North American natural gas. That's exactly why we like our diversified portfolio, which includes many oil-based projects that we can and have been redeploying capital to.
Let me reiterate our overall objectives for the year, which I plan to touch on as we go through the results for the first quarter. Number one, of course, is to maintain our strong base of production, such that when our major projects come on stream, they provide incremental growth. Second, is to continue with significant investments in exploration. Continued exploration will assure the growth momentum beyond the current inventory of major projects that we're developing. Next, we want to maintain our strong financial capacity throughout the year. And finally, we're focused on progressing this lineup of major projects that will clearly deliver transformational impact on reserves and production over the next several years. I think, we made solid progress during the first quarter on these goals.
Looking at our first quarter 2010 results, GAAP net income was $237 million. That was a $1.34 per share diluted on revenues of $733 million. Adjusted net income was $138 million or $0.78 per share with the only adjustment item this quarter, being the unrealized commodity derivative gain.
Sales volumes for the first quarter averaged 197,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which is consistent with the quarterly range we provided you during last quarter's call. Production volumes averaged 201,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which exceeded our sales volumes with the difference due to some specific, the timing on crude oil listings in the North Sea, as well as in Equatorial Guinea.
Our U.S. operations had a very strong quarter, led by our onshore programs, which had record production for the quarter and accounted for approximately 83% of our total U.S. volumes. Onshore, we remain focused on liquid opportunities, led by the Wattenberg field, which continues to deliver, with record organic quarterly volumes and total volumes at about 50,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Another record for Wattenberg was that 50% of our volumes were liquids, either crude or Natural Gas Liquids. Total onshore production was up nearly 6,000 barrels per day equivalent from the fourth quarter, with the majority of the increase coming in crude and Natural Gas Liquids.
Included in our first quarter's volumes is one month impact of the DJ Basin asset acquisition, which added a 1,000 barrels a day of liquids and 12 million cubic feet of gas per day on average for the quarter.
Internationally, our first quarter volumes in Equatorial Guinea were impacted by the scheduled maintenance downtime at the Alba field and the LPG plant there. That maintenance reduced our sales volumes by 4,000 barrels a day of liquids and 49 million cubic feet of natural gas per day on average for the quarter. The maintenance work in Equatorial Guinea is now being completed and was carried out on schedule and on budget.
Natural gas sales in Israel were impacted during the quarter by some power plant downtime, also increased levels of competing imports, as well as warmer-than-usual winter weather. However, the continued strength in oil led to another pricing record for us in Israel. In the North Sea, volumes were up from Dumbarton and Lochranza. However, we were impacted by a couple of operational issues that Dave will talk about in just a few minutes.
Strong NGL pricing continues to enhance our net nat gas prices in certain U.S. locations, which overall, lead to U.S. gas realizations to be slightly above our Henry Hub for the quarter. The increases in crude oil and natural gas liquid realizations have resulted in improved cash margins for us on a unit basis.
At this point, I want to just add a few comments on our hedging activities. This is an important component, supporting our capital programs. Recently, we've taken advantage of the oil markets to add to our hedged positions for 2011, and also began layering in oil contracts for 2012 at some very attractive price levels.
For U.S. natural gas, which only makes up about a third of our global production, we already had approximately two thirds of our volumes hedged for 2010 and we have been increasing our hedge positions in 2011 as well, thus reducing our exposure to gas price volatility during this critical period, where we have significant capital expenditures for our major projects. Just add that all the details on our hedge positions will be found in our first quarter 10-Q, which as David mentioned, will be filed later today.
Looking at our cost performance for the quarter, lease operating expenses came in at just under $5 per barrel equivalent. That reflected lower-than-expected onshore U.S. repairs and workovers. DD&A was pretty consistent with our internal expectations, might have been a little bit higher than what The Street had, had, with the difference being the impact of removing some of those low-cost barrels in Equatorial Guinea due to the maintenance projects there, which of course, then resulted in an overall higher average unit rate for the company for the quarter.
Production taxes, transportation and G&A came in on our expectations on our effective tax rate in deferred portion on adjusted basis were both near the low end of our guidance ranges. On the exploration front, we participated in two of our seven significant wells for the year during the first quarter. Unfortunately, Double Mountain drilled at Green Canyon 555 in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico was non-commercial, so we included $38 million of related cost before tax in the first quarter exploration expense. Our total net cost for the well was approximately $45 million. And you will see the difference, which represents costs incurred in the second quarter. That will, of course, show up in the second quarter earnings. 
At our other ongoing deepwater Gulf of Mexico test Deep Blue, we and our partners decided to extend our planned drilling depth, which has delayed the results there a bit. We expect to have the results in the next month. Looking forward, we plan to appraise our large Gunflint discovery, with one or perhaps two wells and we're preparing for additional exploration tests in both Equatorial Guinea and Israel later in the year.
Total capital expenditures for the quarter were $958 million. That was made up of $408 million for organic CapEx, and then of course approximately $500 million for the DJ Basin asset acquisition. And then in addition, there was another $40 million of non-cash accrual for the construction progress on our FPSO that's going in at Aseng. Our $2.5 billion capital budget remains unchanged for the year. And of course, this is a reminder, that only represents the cash portion of our program. We should see those expenditures build throughout the year, as we develop our major projects in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, West Africa and Israel.
Discretionary cash flow for the quarter was $432 million, which exceeded our organic spending. Total debt at the end the quarter was slightly under $2.4 billion, and we maintained very strong liquidity throughout the period, ending up with $2.5 billion of liquidity between our cash and available credit facility and that's after funding the first quarter acquisition. Our debt to cap net of cash was 17% at the end of the period.
I'll touch briefly on the progress on our major projects before handing it over to Dave. Last year, we sanctioned both Galapagos in the deepwater Gulf and Aseng in Equatorial Guinea, and both of these oil projects continue to move forward. First production from the Galapagos is expected next year and everything's on-schedule to bring Aseng to first production in 2012. We're busy finalizing the development plans at Tamar, offshore Israel and the front-end engineering work at Belinda, offshore Equatorial Guinea is underway, which led to sanctions on both this year. While we have not yet taken Tamar for sanction, our Board has authorized substantial pre-sanction investments. As a result, our procurement teams have been busy letting contracts for supplies and services and the project execution folks are working to ensure we stay on schedule and on budget. So with that, I'll turn it over to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. I plan to focus most of my comments this morning on an update of our main programs around the globe. But before we jump to the activity, I want to start with our expectations for the second quarter and the rest o
componenttext:
Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. I plan to focus most of my comments this morning on an update of our main programs around the globe. But before we jump to the activity, I want to start with our expectations for the second quarter and the rest of the year. Our second quarter volume should be up significantly from the first quarter, led by our operations in Equatorial Guinea coming back online, as well as the full quarter's impact of the onshore U.S. acquisition. Current production is actually running about 212,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, despite approximately 10,000 barrels equivalent per day in the North Sea, which is shut-in, waiting for some facility changes at Dumbarton and Lochranza.
Total company sales for the second quarter are expected to range from 208,000 to 214,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. This includes the impact of the Equatorial Guinea facility modifications for part of April and the assumption of two months downtime for the Dumbarton and Lochranza production. The second half of the year should be significantly higher than the first half, with full production from the North sea, seasonal and demand increases in Israel, the full impact of the Alba production and our continued onshore U.S. growth.
Moving to our activity, let's start onshore in the United States. As Chuck mentioned, we had a stellar first quarter with record production. Currently, our onshore volumes are running a little over 100,000 barrels equivalent per day after the recent acquisition. We expect to be up another 6% to 8% by the end of the year. Activity remains focused on the liquid-rich opportunity set, which has resulted in liquids comprising 40% of our onshore volumes.
Certainly, a key to this program is the core Wattenberg field. Now that, that asset acquisition is closed, our total Wattenberg position is approximately 390,000 net acres, which provides us over a ten-year inventory of development projects. As we integrate the acquisition assets, we'll ramp our activity level to eight or nine rigs during the year. Of our six current drilling rigs in the field, with one focused on our 2010 horizontal Niobrara program, which is testing the potential for increased recoveries in different areas of Wattenberg. This program will provide us production information and data comparisons across a large portion of the field. Outside of Wattenberg, we'll be drilling a handful of horizontal Niobrara test in northern Colorado and Southern Wyoming during second half of the year. Our overall position on the central DJ Basin area of focus now exceeds 730,000 net acres.
As we look at our worldwide capital program, dry gas drilling in the U.S. represents only about 5% of our total 2010 expenditures. In our two active onshore gas programs, the Haynesville and the Piceance, we'll reduce operated activity during the second half of the year. We plan to drop one of our two rigs in the East Texas Haynesville program by June and move our only Piceance rig to Iron Horse around August. These moves reflect our position to continue focusing on liquid-rich activities and essentially shift some gas drilling dollars into our Niobrara program evaluation.
Moving to the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, we mentioned at last quarter's call that we have re-completed the Swordfish well into an oil zone earlier this year. As the well ramped up during the first quarter to its full rate of about 2,500 barrels of oil per day net, we incurred some facility handling problems at the third-party downstream processing facility. This caused us to restrict the field from mid-March through most of April. While the repairs are being performed, we'll restrict the Swordfish by about 6,000 barrels of oil per day net. However, the repairs have been recently completed and Swordfish is now ramping back to full rate.
At Galapagos, the ENSCO 8501 rig spud the Santiago exploration test, and we expect to reach total depth by July. However, based on the proximity to the Horizon rig incident, we'll continue to monitor developments that could affect our operations. Once drilling at Santiago is finished, the rig is expected to handle the completion work at Isabela, Santa Cruz and hopefully, Santiago. This oil development represents the first of a number of major projects that will deliver substantial growth to our company over the next decade.
Our other deepwater Gulf of Mexico rigs should move from Deep Blue in the next month or so to Gunflint to initiate appraisal drilling. We're certainly aware of the interest in Deep Blue, but adhering to our policy of not commenting on ongoing exploration wells, do not expect any news on this well until sometime in May.
The first Gunflint appraisal location is a little over a mile North-Northeast of the original discovery on Block 948, where we will be testing the structure, thickness and contact of the field. Also in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, we were certainly thrilled to have had great success at the March lead sale, where we added 16 additional blocks and a number of attractive prospects to our deep exploration inventory.
Now let's move to International. Starting with Israel, as Chuck mentioned, we achieved a record gas price for the quarter, highlighting the impact of our liquid fuel based sales agreement with the IEC and increasing sales to the Dead Sea Works. As we mentioned in our last quarterly call, the Hagit power plant had downtime during January and part of February. However, it is now fully operational.
Current overall Israel volume is back to our expected level. At Mary-B, we initiated the drilling of two additional development wells, which along with an offshore compression installation planned for later this year, will help to maintain our peak field deliverability at around 600 million cubic feet per day gross. We expect the first well to be completed in the second quarter and the second well in the third quarter. Ultimately, the new wells will also assist the field's long-term use of the storage reserve.
The work to bring Tamar to first production in 2012 is continuing. We're putting in place a number of the long lead major service and equipment contracts consistent with our timeline. Marketing efforts continue, both in securing additional supply agreements and finalizing gas sales and purchase agreements, currently underpinned by the LOIs. We're continuing to work with both local and federal authorities to finalize and approve the onshore receiving terminal location, which will be an important step, as we move to project sanction.
Our processing and interpretation of the 3D seismic acquisition in the region is underway and we expect the final results over the next few months. This will put us in a position to drill an exploration well when our rig arrives early in the fourth quarter.
In the North sea, volumes in the first quarter were up from the fourth quarter 2009 and also up versus the first quarter last year, as a result of facility modifications at Dumbarton and the first Lochranza well, which came online during the first quarter of 2010. We have been impacted by total field shutdowns at the third-party operated Dumbarton/Lochranza project since March. The field is currently shut in and is expected to be back online by the end of May. Upon restart of the field, production will ramp back up and include the impact from the second Lochranza well.
In West Africa, the scheduled downtime for equipment maintenance, upgrades and replacement at the Alba field, as well as the methanol and LPG facilities resulted in the lower first quarter volumes. In addition, the third-party LNG facility had some maintenance performed at the same time. The facilities ramped back up in your April and are now back to full production. Second quarter volumes should be up significantly from the first quarter.
Our field development work at Aseng is progressing nicely. In fact, we now have all the major contracts to be awarded for the project finalized. The prized South Pacific rig began operations in January and is now drilling its second development well. By early June, we expect to have a second rig on location to further assist field development. The hull being converted in to the FPSO arrived in a shipyard at the end of March, and everything looks to be progressing as expected. First production in mid-2012 isn't that far off and the anticipated oil contribution from Aseng will have a meaningful production and cash flow impact on our company.
At Belinda, our next major West Africa project, we're working with our partners to finalize the FEED development work and anticipating submitting the plan of development to the government this quarter. We still expect to mix in an exploration well among our Equatorial Guinea drilling program later this year. In Cameroon, we recently began our 3D seismic shoot of approximately 600 square miles and we plan to process the data the second half of the year.
Before opening the call for questions, I do want to say that we are looking forward to providing further detail on our development operations, the progress of our major projects and our Deep exploration portfolio at our upcoming Analyst Meeting, June 3. We hope you're planning to attend.
With that, Liza, I think we're ready for questions.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Michael Jacobs with Tudor Pickering Holt.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Michael Jacobs with Tudor Pickering Holt.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I would like to ask a couple of conceptual questions if I could. Specifically, when Nobel typically drills subsalt Miocene exploration wells, do you typically target the crest of the structure, given what you see on seismic?
componenttext: I would like to ask a couple of conceptual questions if I could. Specifically, when Nobel typically drills subsalt Miocene exploration wells, do you typically target the crest of the structure, given what you see on seismic?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, what I would say is every exploration opportunity is unique. But one thing, which I think you're aware of, is you just drill the crest of the structure. You may find hydrocarbons, but it won't tell you much about the size of the opportunity. So i
componenttext: I guess, what I would say is every exploration opportunity is unique. But one thing, which I think you're aware of, is you just drill the crest of the structure. You may find hydrocarbons, but it won't tell you much about the size of the opportunity. So in deepwater, where the wells are costly, it's not unusual to be drilling somewhat down dip, such that if you see an oil column, you're confident that there's enough resource up dip of that, that you've got something worth continuing to pursue.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: That kind of leads into my follow-up question, which, what are the possible reasons as to why a company would apply for a permit on the same block, where an exploration well was already drilled, typically? And just thinking, is it side track, is it someth
componenttext: That kind of leads into my follow-up question, which, what are the possible reasons as to why a company would apply for a permit on the same block, where an exploration well was already drilled, typically? And just thinking, is it side track, is it something else typically, if we were to see that in a relatively short period of time?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I really -- I mean, without knowing all the facts of the situation, it would be hard for me to answer that.
componenttext: I really -- I mean, without knowing all the facts of the situation, it would be hard for me to answer that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: When you think about the large-scale development projects, what percentage of reserves do you typical book upon sanctions, just thinking ahead to Tamar and Belinda? Is there a kind of company guideline upon sanction, you'll book x percent of reserves?
componenttext: When you think about the large-scale development projects, what percentage of reserves do you typical book upon sanctions, just thinking ahead to Tamar and Belinda? Is there a kind of company guideline upon sanction, you'll book x percent of reserves?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think you can apply a percentage. I think, what you have to do is look at the data you have at the time of sanction, in terms of the wells that have been drilled, and use appropriate guidelines on what to do as proven. I think, Dave, can provide m
componenttext: I don't think you can apply a percentage. I think, what you have to do is look at the data you have at the time of sanction, in terms of the wells that have been drilled, and use appropriate guidelines on what to do as proven. I think, Dave, can provide maybe a little bit more color. But what we've talked about, for instance, at Aseng is because it's in a relatively new area, we have to be careful about recovery factors. And until you see field performance, you would be limited to what you could say is good solid recovery factors for a field with the amount of data you've got. Tamar is a totally different picture, because it's a gas reservoir and you've got a lot more things you can look at to determine recovery. But again, it depends on at sanction, the data you have. You can't look ahead. So in the case of Aseng, that sanction is based on the wells we have in place, since we do the development program. We'll gather more data and that will likely help and certainly at Tamar, where we have two wells at sanction, that's the only data we'll have and we'll base our reserves on that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think, you're right, Chuck. I think, beyond what you initially book, as you sanction a project, you'll have the additional development, which will give you more information to review and revisit that. And then you'll probably have another c
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think, you're right, Chuck. I think, beyond what you initially book, as you sanction a project, you'll have the additional development, which will give you more information to review and revisit that. And then you'll probably have another cut at it, just to start to get some production in the first year or two, especially on the oil project.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: But no, we don't have a policy of booking x percent or y percent. It's based on appropriate rules that are in place for determining proved reserves and the data that we have at hand.
componenttext: But no, we don't have a policy of booking x percent or y percent. It's based on appropriate rules that are in place for determining proved reserves and the data that we have at hand.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dave Kistler with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dave Kistler with Simmons & Company.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Early on, Chuck, you were talking about the premium afforded to oil and to liquids and kind of how that's not changing your focus, but certainly with some rig moves, increasing your focus on the liquids portion more than it already is. Everybody, or at le
componenttext: Early on, Chuck, you were talking about the premium afforded to oil and to liquids and kind of how that's not changing your focus, but certainly with some rig moves, increasing your focus on the liquids portion more than it already is. Everybody, or at least it seems like, majority of companies that are reporting, are all trying to do that. Can you talk a little bit about what the outlook is for liquids, demand for liquids piece of things in the United States, and whether or not you think that, that could yield some compression actually on the premium that the liquids are getting right now?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, you've got two pieces of course. One is the crude markets, which, there you go into a global market. You really have to look at your global assessment of the oil markets. I think, our view is that it's still a very strong market. Now we do
componenttext: Well, I think, you've got two pieces of course. One is the crude markets, which, there you go into a global market. You really have to look at your global assessment of the oil markets. I think, our view is that it's still a very strong market. Now we do have some, as we've seen in the past, where pushing gets filled up and you see some changes of WTI pricing versus say, as an example, brand. But in the overall scheme of things, I think, that's relatively minor. And the other thing, which you have to be careful on is in remote areas, in the past, we've seen challenges in moving oil out of areas, where the industry has had a surge of activity. That was one of the reasons that we participated in the White Cliffs pipeline that was built out of Wattenberg, so it would give us another outlet for oil there and that is certainly helpful. On the natural gas liquids side, I mean, the margins for processing have been very strong. And again, that's a market that's tended to be a bit of a cyclical market, but it's also being influenced by the oil markets as well. So I think, we still see that as a robust market. I think, while many others are directionally moving their programs, the advantage that Noble has had all along, is we've had the portfolio to be able to move capital. And as you know, we move capital a long time ago into liquids-rich projects. So it's a matter of just continuing that emphasis.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: As we watched others kind of creep into that activity are we seeing any kind of service cost inflation, especially if we start thinking about it with respect to the Wattenberg or the Rockies plays [ph] are targeting the liquid-rich side of things?
componenttext: As we watched others kind of creep into that activity are we seeing any kind of service cost inflation, especially if we start thinking about it with respect to the Wattenberg or the Rockies plays [ph] are targeting the liquid-rich side of things?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dave. I think the thing that you still see the pressure on and we've seen with the rig count going up, you've seen probably a little more pressure on onshore rig. It's not a lot but a little more. The thing up in the Rockies, it doesn't take quite as
componenttext: Yes, Dave. I think the thing that you still see the pressure on and we've seen with the rig count going up, you've seen probably a little more pressure on onshore rig. It's not a lot but a little more. The thing up in the Rockies, it doesn't take quite as big a rig as some of these other plays. We're fortunate in that even some of the vertical rigs, the rigs we've had to be drilling vertical wells, we've got two or three of those that we can actually use for horizontal drilling at least initially in the program if we decide to. I think the thing that still has the most pressure probably is the equipment, especially high-pressure pumping equipment and then some of the frac sands and so forth. I think just availability of those things still have probably a fairly significant pressure on those right now.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just jumping to Haynesville and moving some rigs out of the Piceance as well, but specifically on the Haynesville, can you talk about any maybe HBP requirements that you have in the Haynesville, will you guys be able to maintain that acreage? In
componenttext: And then just jumping to Haynesville and moving some rigs out of the Piceance as well, but specifically on the Haynesville, can you talk about any maybe HBP requirements that you have in the Haynesville, will you guys be able to maintain that acreage? In the past, you've also commented that if pricing environment changed, that might be an area that you would actually add some acreage to. Can you talk about what your current philosophy is right now around that play?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at our current position, we're in good shape as far as being able to hold everything with one rig. In fact, I don't think we'd even have to use the one rig the full year to hold acreage though. We're looking at it from a level of activity th
componenttext: When you look at our current position, we're in good shape as far as being able to hold everything with one rig. In fact, I don't think we'd even have to use the one rig the full year to hold acreage though. We're looking at it from a level of activity there that we're comfortable with the environment. And it just doesn't make sense to keep two rigs for us running there, where we can divert some of that money into some this more liquid-rich piece like additional testing up in the Rockies with some of these properties we've picked up. I think overall, as far as looking for other opportunities, I mean we'll continue to look at things. Nothing jumping out there. But I think the thing we liked about our position down the Haynesville, it gives us firsthand information on some of that activity and not having to rely on third hand reports on what's actually going on down there so we can continue to monitor our results and keep that in mind as we look at other opportunities.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And Dave, I think actually your two questions really link together nicely and you have to think about some of the opportunities that we're seeing, whether it's in Haynesville or other shale place, are being driven by operators who have huge obligations to
componenttext: And Dave, I think actually your two questions really link together nicely and you have to think about some of the opportunities that we're seeing, whether it's in Haynesville or other shale place, are being driven by operators who have huge obligations to hold their leasehold. So it kind of goes counter to our philosophy where we say we don't want to accelerate investments in the dry gas drilling right now. It would run counter for us to jump into an opportunity that has a huge drilling obligation that requires you to ramp up activity over the course of the next 12 to 18 months. So that's another thing that we're very careful about as we look at the opportunities that we don't get caught in a box where we're going to have to employ a lot of capital into a market that we're concerned, we may not be quite ready for it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bob Morris of Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bob Morris of Citigroup.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: You had mentioned that part of the reason Israel volumes were down were competing imports. Can you give a little bit of color on that? Are these imports competing on price or is it just the directive of Israel to diversify their supply? Or what is drivi
componenttext:
You had mentioned that part of the reason Israel volumes were down 
were competing imports. Can you give a little bit of color on that? Are these imports competing on price or is it just the directive of Israel to diversify their supply? Or what is driving that competition that's displacing some of your volumes?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a couple of things. Clearly, there's a bit of trying to diversify supply. Our understanding is, is that the pricing for Egyptian volumes was adjusted up and were probably comparable, although we do have a factor in our agreement that has allowe
componenttext: Well, it's a couple of things. Clearly, there's a bit of trying to diversify supply. Our understanding is, is that the pricing for Egyptian volumes was adjusted up and were probably comparable, although we do have a factor in our agreement that has allowed us to see some really some record pricing. And so, we might be at a maybe a slight price disadvantage on some of our volume. But I think right now, our primary customer is maintaining a diversity of supply. They've got agreements with two suppliers and you couple that with the fact that the weather has been warm and demand has been down and it's allowed them to sort of split their supply between the two of us. But we clearly have the ability to swing with demand and we can swing up very quickly. Dave talking about our maintaining deliverability. So I think our view is that with increased demand through weather and just their own growing power needs, we're in a very good position. But we really, we're just beginning to see the Egyptian imports a little over a year ago. And so that's what's affecting some of our comparisons now as they finally got their system built and got their production stabilized.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Are the Egyptian imports are they on a similar price formula? Similar to your what your contract is? Or is that, where they such that they could provide for the composition price-wise in the future?
componenttext: Are the Egyptian imports are they on a similar price formula? Similar to your what your contract is? Or is that, where they such that they could provide for the composition price-wise in the future?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a bit hard to tell because those agreements are typically non-public documents. We think we're competitive. And once again, we believe that the general market in the Mediterranean for incremental gas is somewhere in that $4 to $5 range that we've tal
componenttext: It's a bit hard to tell because those agreements are typically non-public documents. We think we're competitive. And once again, we believe that the general market in the Mediterranean for incremental gas is somewhere in that $4 to $5 range that we've talked about in the past. And as long as you're in that range, you're competitive. Keep in mind, if you go back to 2008, that was a period when coal prices were very high and actually, our gas was priced very well against the coal imports that Israel is bringing in. So we were actually able to pick up some demand there, with coal prices coming back down, they are obviously, most of the time, keeping their coal plants base loaded.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Leo Mariani with RBC.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Leo Mariani with RBC.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Quick question on the Niobrara. You guys said if you continue to test that play in the DJ. Have you been testing that in Wattenberg proper for a period of time, I'm just curious if you could give us kind anything how long you've kind of been out there a
componenttext:
Quick question on the Niobrara. You guys said if you continue to test that play in the DJ. Have you been testing that in Wattenberg proper for a 
period of time, I'm just curious if you could give us kind anything how long you've kind of been out there and look at this, so we can kind of get a sense of where you are, timeline wise?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've got thousands of wells, vertical wells in Wattenberg that penetrated the Niobrara. So we have a lot of base information that we started looking at probably two to three years ago, we got some additional core data, did some PBT work and so fort
componenttext: Well, we've got thousands of wells, vertical wells in Wattenberg that penetrated the Niobrara. So we have a lot of base information that we started looking at probably two to three years ago, we got some additional core data, did some PBT work and so forth. So this is something we've been looking at fairly hard for a couple of years now, at least a couple of years now. We actually drilled our first horizontal well last year, but we had a chance to start to see some production from that and then compare that to three other wells now over the last year. Mainly last six months or so that we brought online over some wide areas of the field. So we're starting to get a chance to see some things over a little larger area. I think we're just bringing our fifth well on now. So by the end of this year, we should have probably 20 to 25 wells between Wattenberg and outside of Wattenberg and the horizontal play that will give us a pretty wide spectrum of information while we continue to look at core data, understand how these things compare from the vertical well and log information and then incorporate some of the seismic that we're shooting out there. As I've mentioned before, we should have over a couple of hundred square miles of seismic, 3D seismic out here to also tie into this information. So it's not just something that's kind of cropped up overnight. It's something we've be looking at pretty hard for a few years now.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like you guys really haven't kind of come out and put a lot of data around this. I imagine this is probably still a competitive situation from a lease perspective, there's been a couple of operators as well that have kind of announced to pick up
componenttext: It sounds like you guys really haven't kind of come out and put a lot of data around this. I imagine this is probably still a competitive situation from a lease perspective, there's been a couple of operators as well that have kind of announced to pick up positions in that area, I guess just trying to get a sense of you guys are still buying acreage if it's available and are you going to kind of wait before the landgrab before coming out with some info here?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a lot of land running all over the place up there. But with the position that we have in Wattenberg, it's fairly well contained. So our hope is that come June, when we present at our analyst meeting, we'll be able to give you a bit more clea
componenttext: Well, there's a lot of land running all over the place up there. But with the position that we have in Wattenberg, it's fairly well contained. So our hope is that come June, when we present at our analyst meeting, we'll be able to give you a bit more clearer picture as to what we're seeing, at least in the Wattenberg field and what our views are of the potential outside. So just stay tuned for that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question here on China. It looks like your volumes were sort of flat sequentially. I guess I thought that you guys were drilling some horizontal wells there and we just wanted to get a sense of how that's progressing and what we can expect Ch
componenttext: Just a quick question here on China. It looks like your volumes were sort of flat sequentially. I guess I thought that you guys were drilling some horizontal wells there and we just wanted to get a sense of how that's progressing and what we can expect China volumes to look like during the year?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've been in process of bringing on a couple of wells there, but really the majority of what we talked about seeing an increase would be late in the year in China. But I don't see -- I don't think we'll see much change throughout the year. It will b
componenttext: Yes, we've been in process of bringing on a couple of wells there, but really the majority of what we talked about seeing an increase would be late in the year in China. But I don't see -- I don't think we'll see much change throughout the year. It will be kind of more late this year and into next year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Irene Haas with Canaccord Adams.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Irene Haas with Canaccord Adams.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We'd like some color in Israel and just kind of want to be reminded how big is your 3D seismic and the scope of it and you have identified a bunch of leaks already and roughly how many you think you're going to end up with would get hydrated? And the seco
componenttext: We'd like some color in Israel and just kind of want to be reminded how big is your 3D seismic and the scope of it and you have identified a bunch of leaks already and roughly how many you think you're going to end up with would get hydrated? And the second question really has to do with Cyprus. Have you done sort of any work in that particular area? Is there any thought in sort of starting a new sort of exploration program there? And perhaps, actually, ending up with more than just one end-user market i.e. Israel for the gas in the region?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I might let Dave talk a little bit about the scale of the seismic program that we ran in Israel and Cyprus. We expanded it a bit, of course. I think we've talked about that in the past. So we're very pleased with the quality of data we got. We broug
componenttext: Well, I might let Dave talk a little bit about the scale of the seismic program that we ran in Israel and Cyprus. We expanded it a bit, of course. I think we've talked about that in the past. So we're very pleased with the quality of data we got. We brought it in now and we're going through quite a bit of processing on it. So I would just say that there's nothing we've seen that discourages us from the program but it's going to take a little bit further work. We're going to be sitting down with our partners to discuss programs going forward. As we said, we still have expectations that we will be drilling an exploration well there later this year. Irene, I would say that that's another program that we want to talk about quite a bit with you at our June Analyst Meeting. And hopefully give a good picture of what we see for our program going forward. We certainly are excited about this basin and we continue -- there is nothing that's changed on Tamar and Dalit. Those are just wonderful discoveries and certainly, we believe this basin has other potential.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think your point on the size of the seismic program, Irene, I don't have the exact numbers here. But if you think about it, it covered our block in Cyprus and it covered a large portion of the acreage we showed in Israel before. So I think it was r
componenttext: Yes. I think your point on the size of the seismic program, Irene, I don't have the exact numbers here. But if you think about it, it covered our block in Cyprus and it covered a large portion of the acreage we showed in Israel before. So I think it was roughly 1,600 square miles, but don't quote me on that. What it does is it gives us a pretty large playing field to go back and prioritize prospects, and as far as whether it's Cyprus or whether it's Israel, we'll just have to see how they shaped out when we get the 3D in and start to prioritize some of these and setup a program here.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And if Cyprus turned out, say five years forward, turn out to be another really prolific area, sort of any thoughts on building gas, transportation and processing facility and maybe use that particular land base or really lease position to provide an alte
componenttext: And if Cyprus turned out, say five years forward, turn out to be another really prolific area, sort of any thoughts on building gas, transportation and processing facility and maybe use that particular land base or really lease position to provide an alternative way of distributing your likely large gas lines out there?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that our work right now is really almost in three key areas. One obviously is the development of the Tamar field and the marketing that's associated with that. And of course, the second is our ongoing exploration effort, but we also have a thi
componenttext: I would say that our work right now is really almost in three key areas. One obviously is the development of the Tamar field and the marketing that's associated with that. And of course, the second is our ongoing exploration effort, but we also have a third area where we're looking at global gas and as you note, if there's a potential for discovering additional gas resources that will not be needed in the country, in Israel, as an example, then we're looking at the options or markets outside that. And of course for Cyprus, you have to first look at what market is in that country and then also look at external market, if it should exceed it. So that work is underway and so we're pursuing all three of those in parallel.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Stephen Richardson with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Stephen Richardson with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Staying on Israel, just a quick question on the timing of the sanctioning, what really needs to happen? I appreciate that you can spend capital. And that's not holding off the project right now, but in terms of sanctioning, is it the government approving
componenttext: Staying on Israel, just a quick question on the timing of the sanctioning, what really needs to happen? I appreciate that you can spend capital. And that's not holding off the project right now, but in terms of sanctioning, is it the government approving the siting terminal? Is it are you waiting to get more end market contracts? And is any of that kind of impacting your partners' financing? So if you can sort of address what we need to see in order to see that if it's still on track for mid-year?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the key thing with the sanction is especially as you go to the board and you say I have truly defined this project and know have engineered it to the point where you feel confident that you can move forward with massive capital commitments.
componenttext: Well, I think the key thing with the sanction is especially as you go to the board and you say I have truly defined this project and know have engineered it to the point where you feel confident that you can move forward with massive capital commitments. We've made quite a bit so far, but they were in areas that were flexible enough such that if something changed on particular aspects that we could still maintain schedule. The key item which you mentioned is the onshore site location. It's kind of hard to build a bridge until you know where it's going to land on the other side of the water. And we're making great progress on narrowing that down, but until we get at least the clearance and it's narrowed down to a single site, there will still always be lots of work to be done on that site. But as it gets narrowed down, that will be the -- I think, in my view, one of the key factors that will allow us to say we've got the design locked down. We're comfortable that we can bring this to our board and say, "This is the projects that we're going to build." So out of everything, I think that's the more most important thing that we're doing now. And again, that process is moving forward in Israel. We've seen some great progress over the last couple of months on that. We've got some -- right now, we have some commitments from the officials that are involved in those decisions to get us an answer on a single site here very shortly. But until we get that, I think we'll be careful about making the full project commitment that comes with sanction.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan McSpirit with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan McSpirit with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: If I could follow up on a question asked earlier in the period here regarding the industries and the capital markets, unconditional love for all things oil or all things liquid, is there a contrarian in you that would look at gas projects today, given whe
componenttext: If I could follow up on a question asked earlier in the period here regarding the industries and the capital markets, unconditional love for all things oil or all things liquid, is there a contrarian in you that would look at gas projects today, given where gas is trading, are you being presented packages for gas assets, whether conventional or unconventional or are you truly spooked or troubled by the fundamentals for natural gas?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not spooked by the fundamentals of natural gas. I think it's going to continue to be a good market long term. I think we're in a great position for supplying natural gas to customers for decades and it's going to be a good business. But I think
componenttext: Well, I'm not spooked by the fundamentals of natural gas. I think it's going to continue to be a good market long term. I think we're in a great position for supplying natural gas to customers for decades and it's going to be a good business. But I think you have to be careful about when you spend money on it. It looks like it's fully supplied right now. Yes, there are gas opportunities out there. This industry seems to change very quickly and all you have to do is look at the margins associated with oil projects versus gas projects right now. And it's caused many producers to try to think of ways to become more oily. I think we already had our portfolio well diversified, so we are in a very good position to allocate capital. But there's nothing wrong with being countercyclical. If you would have asked me a year and a half ago about making another acquisition in the Rockies, we probably would have said "No, we got too much of that and the Rockies differentials were expanding." But when that market changed and when the differentials shrank and we saw the opportunity at the end of last year, we grabbed it very quickly. So it's all about value. And it's all about making sure that it's value that you can recognize based on your long-term view of the markets. So we're open to opportunities, whether gas and oil, I think that right now, as far as our internal programs, we'd like to invest a project into oil projects because of the margins. But that would not prevent us from picking up a gas opportunity. But as I noted earlier on the call, you have to be careful because many of them being presented now have huge drilling obligations that would force you to put capital into a market that's maybe a bit challenged right now.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then turning quickly to the DJ Basin, particular the Niobrara opportunities there, what is it, recognizing that you do have lots of well controlled to point to, but what is it about that opportunity that you truly find attractive, whether geologically
componenttext: And then turning quickly to the DJ Basin, particular the Niobrara opportunities there, what is it, recognizing that you do have lots of well controlled to point to, but what is it about that opportunity that you truly find attractive, whether geologically and certainly economically, and if you could speak to maybe the targeted economics of that play again, recognize it on a horizontal basis, recognizing of course that it's very, very early innings?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, I think we're going to talk probably quite a bit about that at our June Analyst Meeting. So I won't upstage the folks that are working on that right now. But in general, what we're doing in the Niobrara is no different than what's being done
componenttext: Well, again, I think we're going to talk probably quite a bit about that at our June Analyst Meeting. So I won't upstage the folks that are working on that right now. But in general, what we're doing in the Niobrara is no different than what's being done in a number of other plays across the country. And that is by applying new drilling and completion technology, where it has not been applied before. We clearly see the potential to enhance recoveries, not only on a per well basis, but in terms of on a per unit of capital that's employed. And you're looking at significantly enhanced returns as a result. Why we like the Niobrara, why it's in Wattenberg or outside Wattenberg, within Wattenberg? It's because generally it's had very, very low recoveries in the field. It's been commercially developed using vertical Wells, but it's had very, very low recoveries. And so, applying technology, we certainly believe there is a potential to enhance that recovery and there's a lot in place, a huge amount in place. So there's a great prize. That's why we like it.

componenttext: Yes, Michael. I think no and it's been mentioned earlier, there is still competitive leasing going on in the area. There's still a number of land and actively trying to pick up leasing in the soft side. I think at this point, we really don't want to get into comparing different portions of this. As Chuck mentioned, what we can talk about we'll put together and have much more information in June. But the one thing we don't want to do at this point well is active leasing and so forth is getting to trying to depict a lot of difference in various areas and so forth.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: You got to start with the inventory of projects and there's a huge inventory of projects. I think one of the big factors will be how successful does this kind of horizontal play turn out to be and that will make a big difference as we look to next year an
componenttext: You got to start with the inventory of projects and there's a huge inventory of projects. I think one of the big factors will be how successful does this kind of horizontal play turn out to be and that will make a big difference as we look to next year and the years beyond, as how quickly you can grow some of this. I think the good part is you've got the inventory of projects then we've added that to that inventory of projects with this recent acquisition, that I think we can definitely make it grow. The rate of growth will get a better feel for as we get some more information on how some of this horizontal program works.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think just a follow-up on that because Dave mentioned the acquisition, one of the things we talked about when we made that is that we expected to double that production base by 2012, I believe. So that's just one piece of it. But we just see a lot of op
componenttext: I think just a follow-up on that because Dave mentioned the acquisition, one of the things we talked about when we made that is that we expected to double that production base by 2012, I believe. So that's just one piece of it. But we just see a lot of opportunity and I think, Dave's put the proper precautions on that is we have to see how some of these new plays that we're working here but we are getting information, we're getting results. And so we certainly believe that we've got a sustainable program and we know we've got an inventory of projects because that inventory stretches probably a decade or more.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Many companies in the industry are talking about the mix of oil and gas production that they have and how that might change over time. And as showed in today's results, you're seeing the benefits of growing on the oil side of your business. Would you care
componenttext: Many companies in the industry are talking about the mix of oil and gas production that they have and how that might change over time. And as showed in today's results, you're seeing the benefits of growing on the oil side of your business. Would you care to talk a little about what the mix might look like this year going into next year, going into the year after? Is there any you can talk about at this point?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, our portfolio is a bit unique because of the global side of it. So when you look at our portfolio today, perhaps only 30% of it is U.S. gas. And as we go forward, when we're growing these projects, yes, Galapagos or in Isabela Santa Cruz coming on n
componenttext: Well, our portfolio is a bit unique because of the global side of it. So when you look at our portfolio today, perhaps only 30% of it is U.S. gas. And as we go forward, when we're growing these projects, yes, Galapagos or in Isabela Santa Cruz coming on next year, that will be oil and so that will move the oil mix. So I'd say from a U.S. side of things, I would expect that oil will continue to come up. And that's probably the trend that you would expect to see, especially with the way we've allocated capital. When you look at the global portfolio and you go out to say 2012, you see perhaps a bit more of a balance because you see on Aseng, which is a rich oil project coming on, but it's going to be coupled with Tamar, which is of course a gas project but outside the U.S. and with pricing, that's more tied to global liquids pricing, than certainly it's not tied to U.S. gas markets. So I think the key answer to your question is the U.S. business and clearly, we see the U.S. business going more oily over the next year or two.
