headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to the Noble Energy Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. David Larson. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good morning. Welcome to the Noble Energy Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. David Larson. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Holly. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Noble Energy's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Call and Webcast. On the call today, we have Chuck Davidson, Chairman and CEO; Dave Stover, President and COO; and Ken Fisher, CFO.In a minute, Chuck will revie
componenttext:
Thanks, Holly. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Noble Energy's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Call and Webcast. On the call today, we have Chuck Davidson, Chairman and CEO; Dave Stover, President and COO; and Ken Fisher, CFO.
In a minute, Chuck will review our results for the quarter as well as talk about some of our plans for 2011. Dave will then review our global operations, focused on third quarter highlights and our ongoing activity levels. 
Today, we plan on leaving plenty of time for Q&A at the end of our prepared remarks and wrap up the call in less than an hour. In an effort to ensure that everyone has an opportunity to ask their questions on the call, we would ask that all the participants limit themselves to one primary question and one follow-up.
And should you have any questions that we don't get to, we'll be more than happy to respond to those after the call. We hope everyone has found the earnings release that we issued this morning. Later today, we do expect to be filing our 10-Q with the SEC and we will also have that available on our website.
I want to remind everyone that this webcast and conference call contains projections and forward-looking statements based on our current view and most reasonable expectations. We provide no assurances on these statements as a number of factors and uncertainties could cause actual results in future periods to differ materially from what we discuss here today. You should read our full disclosures on forward-looking statements in our latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of risk factors that influence our business.
We'll reference today certain non-GAAP financial measures here today, such as adjusted net income or discretionary cash flow on the call. When we refer to these items, it's because we believe they are good metrics to use in evaluating the company's performance. Be sure to see the reconciliation in our earnings release tables.
With that, I'm going to turn the call over to Chuck now.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good morning, everyone. In my opening comments, I plan to review our quarterly results and then also walk through some early thoughts for 2011. No question, we had a great third quarter. Record volumes combined with good cost manageme
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good morning, everyone. In my opening comments, I plan to review our quarterly results and then also walk through some early thoughts for 2011. No question, we had a great third quarter. 
Record volumes combined with good cost management delivered GAAP net income of $232 million or $1.31 per diluted share. Adjusted net income was $225 million or $1.27 per diluted share after removing the impact of unrealized commodity derivative gain, also removing the gain on the sale of assets as well as an asset impairment charge.
While the sales numbers are certainly well above expectation, from my perspective, it was really the list of key accomplishments regarding our long-term growth agenda that really made the quarter standout. And these included the sanction of the Tamar project in Israel, significant progress with the horizontal Niobrara play in the DJ Basin and continuing Galapagos in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico despite the moratorium that we have there. These accomplishments are what will really bring great results to our company in the future.
Sales volumes for the third quarter were 230,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Actual production was 2,000 barrels per day above sales due to timing of some international oil listings. Good product diversification continues to be beneficial for us as we have 38% of our sales being global liquids, 33% international gas and the remaining 29% was U.S. gas. Versus the second quarter this year, our international gas percentage was up four points, primarily driven by continued market growth and strong seasonal demand we experienced in Israel, which led to record sales volumes there.
Liquid volumes in the U.S. averaged 54,000 barrels per day in the third quarter, up over 2,000 barrels per day from the second quarter. All volumes in the Central DJ Basin and deepwater Gulf of Mexico were up a combined 5,000 barrels per day, partially offset by nearly a 3,000 barrel a day reduction, which was due to our onshore asset sale that closed during the quarter. 
Our DJ Basin volumes continue to reflect growth from both the vertical and the horizontal development programs. Deepwater was higher as some of our volumes were restricted in the second quarter. We also had increased North Sea volumes primarily from Dumbarton and Lochranza. In Equatorial Guinea, our liquid volumes were down sequentially, due to the timing of liftings during the quarter.
On U.S. natural gas, our volumes declined from the second quarter, primarily resulting from reallocating capital away from dry gas drilling, which of course we began some time ago. Even in Wattenberg, our gas production has declined as we focused on growing liquids in the field. And we'll continue with the same domestic natural gas strategy until the U.S. market is ready for more supply. 
Overall, our U.S. volumes were flat with the second quarter, again keeping in mind that we lost 3,000 barrels a day due to the divestiture. International is up 11,000 barrels a day equivalent for the quarter, that's an 11% increase over the second quarter.
Commodity price realizations were relatively consistent from second quarter to third quarter. Our crude oil average for the quarter was strong at over $73 per barrel and U.S. gas prices were basically flat at $3.87 per Mcf. In Israel, prices were down a little bit due to the changing blend between the old and new gas price advantages at Mari-B. 
Looking at cost that trends from the second to the third quarter was very good, with lease operating expense down 10% on a per barrel basis and transportation and DD&A generally flat. Our exploration activity for the third quarter was relatively quiet and G&A was as expected. The effective tax rate in the third portion on a adjusted basis was lower than we originally anticipated. This resulted from the application of some excess foreign tax credits that we're able to apply to our foreign U.S. branch assets.
The adjustment items to net income for the third quarter include a small gain on the commodity mark-to-market, as well as $114 million pretax gain from the sale of the assets in the Mid-Continent, and the Illinois Basin, again, which closed during the third quarter. We also removed the impact of asset impairments primarily the result of further decline to the natural gas price curve. Finally, we wrote down the value of our New Albany shale assets which we discontinued development activity quite some time ago.
Our balance sheet continues to be very strong. At the end of the quarter, we had over $1.1 billion in cash with the $1.75 billion undrawn on our credit facility, providing us ample flexibilities we invest in our major projects in the coming months. Our total liquidity is right at $2.9 billion. Our debt-to-book capitalization dropped to 25%. And when you net it of cash, it's just 13%, which is six points below where it was just a quarter ago. Our capital spending for the year still looks to be around $2.2 billion.
Switching gears, I thought I'll spend a few minutes on how we're thinking on things as we approached 2011. First for our onshore U.S. program, we've recently added the Central DJ Basin program to a growing list of major projects, and Dave will be discussing the program in greater detail later on the call. 
We view the horizontal Niobrara program in four distinct parts. First off is the core Wattenberg were a substantial amount of vertical development had taken place over the years. And we're now identifying locations for additional horizontal wells. The horizontal potential in the Wattenberg core was highlighted earlier this year by our Gemini well success, and we expect to drill more Gemini-type wells by the end of the year. 
The second area is on the northern and eastern edges of Wattenberg where we're refocusing on expanding the economic limits of the field. A large portion of our horizontal drilling to date has been in this area, and we've been encouraged by flow rates with liquid contributions north of 70%.
Third is our position in northern Colorado from the edges of Wattenberg, basically up to the Wyoming border and the fourth area is our acreage in Southeastern Wyoming and Northwest Weld County, Colorado. Overall, we should be adding two horizontal rigs to the DJ Basin next year. And we expect to drill more than double the number of horizontal wells in 2011 than we will drill this year.
Moving offshore. Despite the Gulf moratorium being formally lifted, we still face a considerable uncertainty there. However, I'm becoming more confident that drilling will resume reasonably soon, perhaps by year end. But almost certainly at a slower pace than pre-moratorium. We're certainly pleased that the completion work at Galapagos has moved forward, and it will truly be an advantage to us that we already have a working certified rig as we prepare to resume drilling. It's our hope that drilling prospects such as Santiago, which is part of Galapagos, the Deep Blue sidetrack and appraisal of our large Gunflint discovery, all of which are targeting known reservoirs will be early candidates for approval.
In the Eastern Med [Mediterranean], we sanctioned Tamar in the third quarter and it's full speed ahead there. We've now awarded the platform fabrication installation contracts as well as the umbilican subsea installation in all major subsea equipment as ordered. The rig will commence field developments in the first quarter of next year following exploration results of Leviathan which initiated drilling about a week and a half ago. 
Our second rig will come into the area early next year to provide further support to our exploration and appraisal plan. So we'll have two rigs working in the Eastern Mediterranean for at least a good portion of 2011.
Our next will certainly be very active for us. Overall, our goals are to keep our major project developments on schedule, expand the horizontal Niobrara program and resume deepwater Gulf of Mexico drilling activity. On top of that, we're focused on leveraging our prior success in exploring offshore West Africa and the Eastern Mediterranean. And of course, supporting these objectives is maintaining a strong balance sheet, which we have. 
We'll be finalizing our capital budget over the next few months, but I would expect that it will be consistent with what we laid out in our June Analyst Meeting. The Mid-Continent and Illinois Basin production that we sold partway to this year which totals approximately 6,000 barrels a day equivalent will obviously impact 2011 volumes. But even so, we expect volume growth next year, which will likely be in the low-single digits on a percentage basis. Of course our growth will rapidly accelerate as the major projects start up, so as we move closer to 2012, we should see the beginning of a significant step up in both production and cash flow, as well as an accelerating growth rate, led by our strong-based programs and the impact of our major project developments.
So that's just a quick glimpse of what we see for 2011. And so with that, I'll turn the call over to you, Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chuck. Starting in the U.S., our plan to focus on our activity levels, recent results and where our programs are headed the remainder of this year and into next year. It was another great quarter for our onshore business led by the Central DJ Ba
componenttext:
Thanks, Chuck. Starting in the U.S., our plan to focus on our activity levels, recent results and where our programs are headed the remainder of this year and into next year. 
It was another great quarter for our onshore business led by the Central DJ Basin. With a strong liquid focus, we've been able to grow our net crude oil production at the basin by over 2,500 barrels per day compared to the second quarter average of this year. Total liquid production in this area averaged over 30,000 barrels a day in the third quarter and our liquid percent has grown to 54% of total basin production. Actual crude oil and condensate made up 21,000 barrels per day in the third quarter.
We're operating six vertical rigs in Wattenberg and our Niobrara horizontal rig count has grown to three, with two rigs currently in Wattenberg and one on our Southeastern Wyoming acreage. Our net acreage in the basin is now over 830,000, an increase of 80,000 acres since June with the majority of the additions coming from areas outside of Wattenberg. 
So far this year, we've drilled 15 wells in Wattenberg, two in the core and 13 tests in the northern and eastern edges of the field. Recent horizontal well results in Wattenberg continued to be encouraging with the last 11 wells having initial 24 hour rates between 550 and 850 barrels of oil equivalent per day with high oil content. Some of the wells drilled on the edges of the field have been in areas we would consider marginally economic for vertical well development, making areas that previously didn't work now viable with current technology. 
As we continue to obtain more production history, estimated ultimate recoveries are tracking on average with our 290,000 barrel of oil equivalent scenario. In total, we have 15 horizontal wells on production in Wattenberg, including the three wells that were drilled in 2009. Our teams continued to improve drill times, highlighted by recent wells with a spud to TD in less than 15 days. On the completion side, bilateral lengths range from 3,300 to 5,100 feet. The number of fracs stages per well has increased to 18 to 20 stages.
We recently moved one of the horizontal rig back to the core area of Wattenberg few miles from our Gemini well, where we will be further testing recovery in a more vertically developed portion of the field. Gemini has now produced over 160,000 barrels of oil equivalent in just seven months, and is still producing over 400 barrels of oil equivalent per day with liquid representing 30% to 40% of the volume. We also recently finished the horizontal Codell well and are drilling a second, targeting both the Codell and the Niobrara zones, but we're still testing and evaluating different completion scenarios in these early stage of the play.
In our third focus area, Northern Colorado, we have drilled and completed four wells around the Grover area. The first two wells, we're targeting quite areas identified on the 3D where we're testing the matrix contribution. Despite the lack of natural fractures, initial 24 hour rates were 500 to 600 barrels of oil equivalent per day with around 85% oil contribution. These wells have been on production in less than 60 days, and we're working to determine the optimum production lift system as there is less reservoir energy in this area north of Wattenberg. 
Our third and fourth wells were a few miles to the east in an area with more natural fractures. They were recently completed in our cleaning up after stimulation.
And the fourth area of focus in Southeast Wyoming, we're now drilling our second of three wells combining 3D seismic data with core and well information gained from vertical monitoring wells, all of which will help in evaluating this portion of the play. The first horizontal well was fracture stimulated this week.
In total, we're still planning to have about 30 horizontal Niobrara wells drilled in the basin this year. Around 21 in Wattenberg, about six in Northern Colorado and three in Southeast Wyoming.
Based on our results today and encouragement about the play, we currently plan to add a fourth horizontal rig in the second quarter next year and a fifth in the third quarter. As Chuck mentioned, our plan's to have us doubling our horizontal Niobrara drilling activity next year. We will also continue acquiring 3D seismic, adding another thousand square miles to the 300 we expect to have by the end of this year.
In the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, the ENSCO 8501 rig has completed Santa Cruz and will complete work in Isabela in the next few days finishing almost all the Galapagos project that we operate. BP is working on a subsea gathering system and tie in, as well as the top sites at Na Kika. The latest schedule has the late barge coming in around the first of April next year with initial production in the second half of the year. We're still expecting in the range of 8,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day net when it comes online.
At our Retarm [ph] South oil project, we have recently approved the plan of development which is targeting the addition of 3,000 to 4,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day net by the end of 2011. The well was drilled and completed in 2008, and we're finalizing the production handling agreement.
Following the lifting of the deepwater Gulf of Mexico moratorium, we have submitted permit applications to resume drilling operations at Santiago and the Deep Blue sidetrack. We plan to submit a permit for the Gunflint appraisal well shortly.
Turning to our international program. At the Aseng oil project in Equatorial Guinea, our two rigs have finished drilling operations and are now performing well completions. As a reminder, Aseng is being developed with five horizontal producers, three water injectors and two gas injectors. We're pleased with the results from the drilling program coming in under budget and with oil and plays numbers increasing slightly. We've landed all 10 of the subsea trees and everything is moving forward as expected including the FPSO conversion, start up the still plan for mid-2012 with 17,000 barrels of oil per day net.
At Alen, all FEED and early design work has been completed. We expect to have project sanctioned in the next couple of months. We have awarded contracts for the platform, subsea trees and installation of pipeline. And field start up is expected by the end of 2013. Between Aseng and Alen, we should see an increase of more than 30,000 barrels of liquids per day net by the end of 2013.
As we process new 3D data from Cameroon, and reprocess our Equatorial Guinea 3D, we're prioritizing our exploration plans for next year in the Douala Basin. The 2011 targets will be additional oil opportunities in the range of 100 million barrels gross or greater, mostly in the Miocene or perhaps seems slightly deeper. Overall, we believe we will have between two and four exploration wells in this basin next year.
In the North Sea, we received temporary relief related to the meant [ph] stock issue on the Dumbarton FPSO. As a result, total North Sea volumes were up 45% from the second quarter, reflecting improved sales since from Dumbarton and Lochranza. There is some compression system maintenance on going at Dumbarton and that will restrict our rates just a bit in the fourth quarter. 
In Israel, we completed the second of two new development wells at Mari-B in mid-September. Strong natural gas demand has allowed us to test the productivity of our new wells, one of which flowed as much as 225 million cubic feet a day, with the completion similar to what we're finding at Tamar. The addition of these two wells, along with compression in the first half of 2011, allows us to maintain full field deliverability, 600 million cubic feet a day gross until Tamar comes online. Overall, it was a quarter of exceptional operational performance in Israel, meeting record gas demand reliably, bringing two new wells online and continuing our outstanding safety performance.
Once the said coach press rig completes our exploration test at Leviathan, we will begin development drilling at Tamar. Leviathan is now drilling, and we anticipate seeing results by the end of the year. Again, this is a 16 trillion cubic foot gross prospect with a 50% chance of success. Chuck mentioned that we will bring a second rig to the region early next year. Depending on results from the Leviathan well, I would expect that we will drill between two and four exploration or appraisal wells in the area in 2011 as we continue to test the potential of this under-explored basin. We have recently completed additional 3D seismic acquisition offshore Israel adding another 925 square miles of coverage.
Turning to our total company sales outlook for the fourth quarter, volumes should range between 212 to 222,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Combined with strong sales year-to-date, our full year average outlook has increased into the upper half of our previous guidance or 214,000 to 217,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
In the U.S., the fourth quarter will not include any volumes from the 6,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day divestiture that closed in August. Compared to the third quarter, natural gas sales volumes in Israel will be down due to the seasonality and the North Sea and deepwater Gulf of Mexico volumes will see some decline. We expect our Central DJ Basin volumes will continue to show growth and oil volumes in Equatorial Guinea should be higher as the third quarter was an underlifted period.
Our activity level remains high as we rapidly approach 2011. We will continue to gather more information on the horizontal Niobrara program while prepare for our return to drilling in the Gulf of Mexico. Internationally, we're focused on keeping both Aseng and Alen moving in West Africa and Tamar in Israel. We should have results from Leviathan by the end of the year. That's a quick look at our key activities. So Holly, I think now we're ready to open it up for questions.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Couple of questions both on the Niobrara, can you add a bit more color on the two wells that you drilled with seismic outside Wattenberg, without natural fractures I know it's early but any read across from these results regarding the potential efficacy of that matrix flow outside of Wattenberg?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Really not a whole lot to add at this time, Brian. As you said, we drilled two there now. We drilled them in what we would have -- that made it as quiet areas, very little fracturing expectation. We saw nice initial rates that 500 to 600 barrels a day as
componenttext: Really not a whole lot to add at this time, Brian. As you said, we drilled two there now. We drilled them in what we would have -- that made it as quiet areas, very little fracturing expectation. We saw nice initial rates that 500 to 600 barrels a day as we brought them on, and we're still just a couple of months into that. And we just have to get some more time to see how they produce. The main thing up here, you remember compared to -- in Wattenberg they have much less gas production and DOR is probably closer to around 1,000 in this area. So we just got to give them some time to produce. But we're encouraged with what we've seen so far. And as we mentioned, we're stepping out now and going to test some areas that look like has a little more folding expectation and a little more fracturing, and we're just starting to clean those wells up and then we'll have a chance to compare those over the next couple of months.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, I think you'd mentioned in your comments that you're seeing some areas work to a greater degree using vertical wells that you didn't think where it worked before. I believe that your analyst is bending you to talk about almost double t
componenttext: And as a follow-up, I think you'd mentioned in your comments that you're seeing some areas work to a greater degree using vertical wells that you didn't think where it worked before. I believe that your analyst is bending you to talk about almost double the IRR, the rate of return from drilling horizontally versus Codell and Niobrara vertical well. And I guess I was wondering if that is changing a little bit where the vertical wells are, are you seeing better returns from vertical drilling and what's driving that?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me just clarify that a little, Brian. What I was mentioning was in some of the areas where vertical wells are maybe a little more marginal like up in the north and to the east. We're actually seeing some nice horizontal results and what I was rea
componenttext: Yes, let me just clarify that a little, Brian. What I was mentioning was in some of the areas where vertical wells are maybe a little more marginal like up in the north and to the east. We're actually seeing some nice horizontal results and what I was really trying to get across is the horizontal results are opening up some areas that maybe weren't as attractive vertically.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, we're wrapping up our budget works, so we don't have it finalized. But I think one thing that you can tie it off from is the drilling activity, which we noted we expected to be basically double what we're doing in this year, certainly from a well c
componenttext: Again, we're wrapping up our budget works, so we don't have it finalized. But I think one thing that you can tie it off from is the drilling activity, which we noted we expected to be basically double what we're doing in this year, certainly from a well count standpoint. So that will drive additional capital into the DJ Basin and so, that is our plan right now. We expect to maintain a very strong legacy program in Wattenberg. So we're not rubbing that. This is -- I think it's safe to say, it's very much an incremental program. But we're still working on the parts of the basin that we'll go into. We're obviously going to be working in all the areas that we outlined and we'll get that finalized. But it will be a substantial program.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, Dave, just to that same extent, what you'll see next year probably is -- from compared to this year, we'll be moving some of what was lease acquisition capital this year up in that basin into drilling capital next year.
componenttext: Yes, I guess, Dave, just to that same extent, what you'll see next year probably is -- from compared to this year, we'll be moving some of what was lease acquisition capital this year up in that basin into drilling capital next year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up, moving to the Gulf of Mexico for a second, you mentioned on the call that you thought that you might see some drilling activity by year end. Can you kind of maybe differentiate whether that would be appraisal drilling, whether you think we
componenttext: As a follow-up, moving to the Gulf of Mexico for a second, you mentioned on the call that you thought that you might see some drilling activity by year end. Can you kind of maybe differentiate whether that would be appraisal drilling, whether you think we'll actually start to see true exploration drilling again? And maybe just a little bit more color on the outlook there especially how it relates to what kind of timing that looks like and then also what that means with respect to expenses in terms of cost to drill and work through programs.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, the operative word is hope. I hope that we'll see something by the end of the year. And the only reason I say that is as Dave pointed out, we have submitted the applications to resume work on two wells we're drilling at the time of the morator
componenttext: Sure. Well, the operative word is hope. I hope that we'll see something by the end of the year. And the only reason I say that is as Dave pointed out, we have submitted the applications to resume work on two wells we're drilling at the time of the moratorium, that was Santiago and Deep Blue. So certainly, we would expect that those -- whenever we receive approval, it will be one of those that will likely get early approval. And as I noted, I was hopeful that those and perhaps Gunflint might be early on the queue because we were drilling into known reservoirs. One has been penetrated before and so in our view, it's more likely that those types of operations might get earlier approval than sheer rank exploration. I only say that because some of the experience that other companies had when they were resuming operations in the shallow water that those that were more known and viewed to be, they could be easily looked through when you had known pore pressures and regimes and drilling programs that they be might level up as early approval. When that will happen -- I'm only speculating because that review process started. Again I noted, we do have a positive, these are being permitted on the ENSCO rig that is actually been working during the moratorium. It was very early certified. And so we've got what we believe is a working certified rig, so that part of it we can work through. There's still more things that have to be done. And clearly, our experience to get the Galapagos completion permit was that they had a lot of work and a lot of iterations to go through. So I would not expect anything to be just as sended in and then comes back approved. I would think that there will be some iterations in these drilling permits. So if anything happens, I would say it's going to have very little cost impact on this year. Our view is that all of this will be part of our 2011 plans and we certainly got flexibility to accommodate the schedule, whatever turns out.

componenttext: I think the uncertainty is as you start to move north of Wattenberg as you get into the Northern Colorado and Southern Wyoming areas, and I think the question there is that all of us are looking at and trying to understand is what is the contribution for matrix versus fractures and how dependent one versus the other in those areas. And that's why we're still really early in this game of trying to understand and help in defining what are the areas that are really going to be economically attractive as we go up through the north of this play.

componenttext: Not to a large extent. I think what I'm saying is we're integrating that with REG. But we have now a more regional picture. I think what I alluded to is we're looking at prospects of a fairly large size over 100 million barrels or greater. And we're seeing a few prospects bubble up there and that's what we're starting to get ready in the queue and sort through as to which ones we'll be drilling. I think we'll have some -- I would expect we'll have some activity in Cameroon next year. And then that will give us a chance to compare some additional oil exploration in that area along with what we've already seen over on the EG [Equatorial Guinea] side. So we'll start to get a much larger regional picture over there. If you remember, we got over 1 million acres over there and very little of it has been explored down here into the Miocene or below.

componenttextpreview: Well, if you look at it, it takes two to three weeks to drill a well. And then to complete them, it will get completed over the next month or so. So I'd  say at any point in time, with two to three rigs running, we'll have a backlog running into the end o
componenttext: Well, if you look at it, it takes two to three weeks to drill a well. And then to complete them, it will get completed over the next month or so. So I'd  say at any point in time, with two to three rigs running, we'll have a backlog running into the end of the year, four to six wells maybe. And that kind of how it flows through. I'd say when you look at 2011, by the end of 2011, you're looking at the same type of thing where you have probably a months worth of drilling that you're still waiting to complete at any point in time.

componenttextpreview: There's a couple of things and it's not all driven by geology. Some as In our own minds, some has to do with the infrastructure availability, where once you get up into Wyoming, it really starts to disappear on you. And so, your pace of work is somewhat l
componenttext: There's a couple of things and it's not all driven by geology. Some as In our own minds, some has to do with the infrastructure availability, where once you get up into Wyoming, it really starts to disappear on you. And so, your pace of work is somewhat limited by accommodating and building out infrastructure. So one of the things that is probably affecting our scale of program in 2011 the most is just making sure that we have infrastructure to be able to continue to test and produce wells. So that's probably one of the primary things. Those two areas are both well a way from Wattenberg so they're not influenced by the Wattenberg geology. But they do have differences in infrastructure. We've got in the Grover area, we had some existing ongoing development there. We've got some ability to handle production better. And so, we did focus some of our work there. So that I think is one of the primary drivers on those two areas.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Holly. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Noble Energy's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Call and Webcast. On the call today, we have Chuck Davidson, Chairman and CEO; Dave Stover, President and COO; and Ken Fisher, CFO.In a minute, Chuck will revie
componenttext:
Thanks, Holly. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Noble Energy's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Call and Webcast. On the call today, we have Chuck Davidson, Chairman and CEO; Dave Stover, President and COO; and Ken Fisher, CFO.
In a minute, Chuck will review our results for the quarter as well as talk about some of our plans for 2011. Dave will then review our global operations, focused on third quarter highlights and our ongoing activity levels. 
Today, we plan on leaving plenty of time for Q&A at the end of our prepared remarks and wrap up the call in less than an hour. In an effort to ensure that everyone has an opportunity to ask their questions on the call, we would ask that all the participants limit themselves to one primary question and one follow-up.
And should you have any questions that we don't get to, we'll be more than happy to respond to those after the call. We hope everyone has found the earnings release that we issued this morning. Later today, we do expect to be filing our 10-Q with the SEC and we will also have that available on our website.
I want to remind everyone that this webcast and conference call contains projections and forward-looking statements based on our current view and most reasonable expectations. We provide no assurances on these statements as a number of factors and uncertainties could cause actual results in future periods to differ materially from what we discuss here today. You should read our full disclosures on forward-looking statements in our latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of risk factors that influence our business.
We'll reference today certain non-GAAP financial measures here today, such as adjusted net income or discretionary cash flow on the call. When we refer to these items, it's because we believe they are good metrics to use in evaluating the company's performance. Be sure to see the reconciliation in our earnings release tables.
With that, I'm going to turn the call over to Chuck now.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good morning, everyone. In my opening comments, I plan to review our quarterly results and then also walk through some early thoughts for 2011. No question, we had a great third quarter. Record volumes combined with good cost manageme
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good morning, everyone. In my opening comments, I plan to review our quarterly results and then also walk through some early thoughts for 2011. No question, we had a great third quarter. 
Record volumes combined with good cost management delivered GAAP net income of $232 million or $1.31 per diluted share. Adjusted net income was $225 million or $1.27 per diluted share after removing the impact of unrealized commodity derivative gain, also removing the gain on the sale of assets as well as an asset impairment charge.
While the sales numbers are certainly well above expectation, from my perspective, it was really the list of key accomplishments regarding our long-term growth agenda that really made the quarter standout. And these included the sanction of the Tamar project in Israel, significant progress with the horizontal Niobrara play in the DJ Basin and continuing Galapagos in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico despite the moratorium that we had there. These accomplishments are what will really bring great results to our company in the future.
Sales volumes for the third quarter were 230,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Actual production was 2,000 barrels per day above sales due to timing of some international oil liftings. Good product diversification continues to be beneficial for us as we have 38% of our sales being global liquids, 33% international gas and the remaining 29% was U.S. gas. Versus the second quarter this year, our international gas percentage was up four points, primarily driven by continued market growth and strong seasonal demand we experienced in Israel, which led to record sales volumes there.
Liquid volumes in the U.S. averaged 54,000 barrels per day in the third quarter, up over 2,000 barrels per day from the second quarter. All volumes in the Central DJ Basin and deepwater Gulf of Mexico were up a combined 5,000 barrels per day, partially offset by nearly a 3,000 barrel a day reduction, which was due to our onshore asset sale that closed during the quarter. 
Our DJ Basin volumes continue to reflect growth from both the vertical and the horizontal development programs. Deepwater was higher as some of our volumes were restricted in the second quarter. We also had increased North Sea volumes primarily from Dumbarton and Lochranza. In Equatorial Guinea, our liquid volumes were down sequentially, due to the timing of liftings during the quarter.
On U.S. natural gas, our volumes declined from the second quarter, primarily resulting from reallocating capital away from dry gas drilling, which of course we began some time ago. Even in Wattenberg, our gas production has declined as we focused on growing liquids in the field. And we'll continue with the same domestic natural gas strategy until the U.S. market is ready for more supply. 
Overall, our U.S. volumes were flat with the second quarter, again keeping in mind that we lost 3,000 barrels a day due to the divestiture. International is up 11,000 barrels a day equivalent for the quarter, that's an 11% increase over the second quarter.
Commodity price realizations were relatively consistent from second quarter to third quarter. Our crude oil average for the quarter was strong at over $73 per barrel and U.S. gas prices were basically flat at $3.87 per Mcf. In Israel, prices were down a little bit due to the changing blend between the old and new gas price advantages at Mari-B. 
Looking at cost the trend from the second to the third quarter was very good, with lease operating expense down 10% on a per barrel basis and transportation and DD&A generally flat. Our exploration activity for the third quarter was relatively quiet and G&A was as expected. The effective tax rate and deferred portion on an adjusted basis was lower than we originally anticipated. This resulted from the application of some excess foreign tax credits that we're able to apply to our foreign U.S. branch assets.
The adjustment items to net income for the third quarter include a small gain on the commodity mark-to-market, as well as $114 million pretax gain from the sale of the assets in the Mid-Continent, and the Illinois Basin, again, which closed during the third quarter. We also removed the impact of asset impairments primarily the result of further decline to the natural gas price curve. Finally, we wrote down the value of our New Albany shale assets which we discontinued development activity quite some time ago.
Our balance sheet continues to be very strong. At the end of the quarter, we had over $1.1 billion in cash with the $1.75 billion undrawn on our credit facility, providing us ample flexibility as we invest in our major projects in the coming months. Our total liquidity is right at $2.9 billion. Our debt-to-book capitalization dropped to 25%. And when you net it of cash, it's just 13%, which is six points below what it was just a quarter ago. Our capital spending for the year still looks to be around $2.2 billion.
Switching gears, I thought Iâ€™d spend a few minutes on how we're thinking on things as we approach 2011. First for our onshore U.S. program, we've recently added the Central DJ Basin program to a growing list of major projects, and Dave will be discussing the program in greater detail later on the call. 
We view the horizontal Niobrara program in four distinct parts. First off is the core Wattenberg where a substantial amount of vertical development had taken place over the years. And we're now identifying locations for additional horizontal wells. The horizontal potential in the Wattenberg core was highlighted earlier this year by our Gemini well success, and we expect to drill more Gemini-type wells by the end of the year. 
The second area is on the northern and eastern edges of Wattenberg where we're focusing on expanding the economic limits of the field. A large portion of our horizontal drilling to date has been in this area, and we've been encouraged by flow rates with liquid contributions north of 70%.
Third is our position in northern Colorado from the edges of Wattenberg, basically up to the Wyoming border and the fourth area is our acreage in Southeastern Wyoming and Northwest Weld County, Colorado. Overall, we should be adding two horizontal rigs to the DJ Basin next year. And we expect to drill more than double the number of horizontal wells in 2011 than we will drill this year.
Moving offshore. Despite the Gulf moratorium being formally lifted, we still face a considerable uncertainty there. However, I'm becoming more confident that drilling will resume reasonably soon, perhaps by year end. But almost certainly at a slower pace than pre-moratorium. We're certainly pleased that the completion work at Galapagos has moved forward, and it will truly be an advantage to us that we already have a working certified rig as we prepare to resume drilling. It's our hope that drilling prospects such as Santiago, which is part of Galapagos, the Deep Blue sidetrack and appraisal of our large Gunflint discovery, all of which are targeting known reservoirs will be early candidates for approval.
In the Eastern Med [Mediterranean], we sanctioned Tamar in the third quarter and it's full speed ahead there. We've now awarded the platform fabrication installation contracts as well as the umbilican subsea installation in all major subsea equipment as ordered. The rig will commence field developments in the first quarter of next year following exploration results of Leviathan which initiated drilling about a week and a half ago. 
Our second rig will come into the area early next year to provide further support to our exploration and appraisal plan. So we'll have two rigs working in the Eastern Mediterranean for at least a good portion of 2011.
Our next year will certainly be very active for us. Overall, our goals are to keep our major project developments on schedule, expand the horizontal Niobrara program and resume deepwater Gulf of Mexico drilling activity. On top of that, we're focused on leveraging our prior success in exploring offshore West Africa and the Eastern Mediterranean. And of course, supporting these objectives is maintaining a strong balance sheet, which we have. 
We'll be finalizing our capital budget over the next few months, but I would expect that it will be consistent with what we laid out in our June Analyst Meeting. The Mid-Continent and Illinois Basin production that we sold partway to this year which totals approximately 6,000 barrels a day equivalent will obviously impact 2011 volumes. But even so, we expect volume growth next year, which will likely be in the low-single digits on a percentage basis. Of course our growth will rapidly accelerate as the major projects start up, so as we move closer to 2012, we should see the beginning of a significant step up in both production and cash flow, as well as an accelerating growth rate, led by our strong-based programs and the impact of our major project developments.
So that's just a quick glimpse of what we see for 2011. And so with that, I'll turn the call over to you, Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chuck. Starting in the U.S., I plan to focus on our activity levels, recent results and where our programs are headed the remainder of this year and into next year. It was another great quarter for our onshore business led by the Central DJ Basi
componenttext:
Thanks, Chuck. Starting in the U.S., I plan to focus on our activity levels, recent results and where our programs are headed the remainder of this year and into next year. 
It was another great quarter for our onshore business led by the Central DJ Basin. With a strong liquid focus, we've been able to grow our net crude oil production at the basin by over 2,500 barrels per day compared to the second quarter average of this year. Total liquid production in this area averaged over 30,000 barrels a day in the third quarter and our liquid percent has grown to 54% of total basin production. Actual crude oil and condensate made up 21,000 barrels per day in the third quarter.
We're operating six vertical rigs in Wattenberg and our Niobrara horizontal rig count has grown to three, with two rigs currently in Wattenberg and one on our Southeastern Wyoming acreage. Our net acreage in the basin is now over 830,000, an increase of 80,000 acres since June with the majority of the additions coming from areas outside of Wattenberg. 
So far this year, we've drilled 15 wells in Wattenberg, two in the core and 13 tests in the northern and eastern edges of the field. Recent horizontal well results in Wattenberg continued to be encouraging with the last 11 wells having initial 24 hour rates between 550 and 850 barrels of oil equivalent per day with high oil content. Some of the wells drilled on the edges of the field have been in areas we would consider marginally economic for vertical well development, making areas that previously didn't work now viable with current technology. 
As we continue to obtain more production history, estimated ultimate recoveries are tracking on average with our 290,000 barrel of oil equivalent scenario. In total, we have 15 horizontal wells on production in Wattenberg, including the three wells that were drilled in 2009. Our teams continued to improve drill times, highlighted by recent wells with a spud to TD in less than 15 days. On the completion side, the lateral lengths range from 3,300 to 5,100 feet. The number of fracs stages per well has increased to 18 to 20 stages.
We recently moved one of the horizontal rig back to the core area of Wattenberg few miles from our Gemini well, where we will be further testing recovery in a more vertically developed portion of the field. Gemini has now produced over 160,000 barrels of oil equivalent in just seven months, and is still producing over 400 barrels of oil equivalent per day with liquid representing 30% to 40% of the volume. We also recently finished the horizontal Codell well and are drilling a second, targeting both the Codell and the Niobrara zones, but we're still testing and evaluating different completion scenarios in these early stage of the play.
In our third focus area, Northern Colorado, we have drilled and completed four wells around the Grover area. The first two wells, we're targeting quiet areas identified on the 3D where we're testing the matrix contribution. Despite the lack of natural fractures, initial 24 hour rates were 500 to 600 barrels of oil equivalent per day with around 85% oil contribution. These wells have been on production in less than 60 days, and we're working to determine the optimum production lift system as there is less reservoir energy in this area north of Wattenberg. 
Our third and fourth wells were a few miles to the east in an area with more natural fractures. They were recently completed and are cleaning up after stimulation.
And the fourth area of focus in Southeast Wyoming, we're now drilling our second of three wells combining 3D seismic data with core and log information gained from vertical monitoring wells, all of which will help in evaluating this portion of the play. The first horizontal well was fracture stimulated this week.
In total, we're still planning to have about 30 horizontal Niobrara wells drilled in the basin this year. Around 21 in Wattenberg, about six in Northern Colorado and three in Southeast Wyoming.
Based on our results today and encouragement about the play, we currently plan to add a fourth horizontal rig in the second quarter next year and a fifth in the third quarter. As Chuck mentioned, our plans have us doubling our horizontal Niobrara drilling activity next year. We will also continue acquiring 3D seismic, adding another thousand square miles to the 300 we expect to have by the end of this year.
In the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, the ENSCO 8501 rig has completed Santa Cruz and will complete work in Isabela in the next few days finishing almost all the Galapagos project that we operate. BP is working on a subsea gathering system and tie in, as well as the top sites [ph] at Na Kika. The latest schedule has the lay barge coming in around the first of April next year with initial production in the second half of the year. We're still expecting in the range of 8,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day net when it comes online.
At our Retarm [ph] South oil project, we have recently approved the plan of development which is targeting the addition of 3,000 to 4,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day net by the end of 2011. The well was drilled and completed in 2008, and we're finalizing the production handling agreement.
Following the lifting of the deepwater Gulf of Mexico moratorium, we have submitted permit applications to resume drilling operations at Santiago and the Deep Blue sidetrack. We plan to submit a permit for the Gunflint appraisal well shortly.
Turning to our international program. At the Aseng oil project in Equatorial Guinea, our two rigs have finished drilling operations and are now performing well completions. As a reminder, Aseng is being developed with five horizontal producers, three water injectors and two gas injectors. We're pleased with the results from the drilling program coming in under budget and with oil and plays numbers increasing slightly. We've landed all 10 of the subsea trees and everything is moving forward as expected including the FPSO conversion.  Start up is still planned for mid-2012 with 17,000 barrels of oil per day net.
At Alen, all FEED and early design work has been completed. We expect to have project sanctioned in the next couple of months. We have awarded contracts for the platform, subsea trees and installation of pipeline. And field start up is expected by the end of 2013. Between Aseng and Alen, we should see an increase of more than 30,000 barrels of liquids per day net by the end of 2013.
As we process new 3D data from Cameroon, and reprocess our Equatorial Guinea 3D, we're prioritizing our exploration plans for next year in the Douala Basin. The 2011 targets will be additional oil opportunities in the range of 100 million barrels gross or greater, mostly in the Miocene or perhaps seems slightly deeper. Overall, we believe we will have between two and four exploration wells in this basin next year.
In the North Sea, we received temporary relief related to the vent stack issue on the Dumbarton FPSO. As a result, total North Sea volumes were up 45% from the second quarter, reflecting improved sales since from Dumbarton / Lochranza. There is some compression system maintenance on going at Dumbarton and that will restrict our rates just a bit in the fourth quarter. 
In Israel, we completed the second of two new development wells at Mari-B in mid-September. Strong natural gas demand has allowed us to test the productivity of our new wells, one of which flowed as much as 225 million cubic feet a day, with the completion similar to what we're finding at Tamar. The addition of these two wells, along with compression in the first half of 2011, allows us to maintain full field deliverability, 600 million cubic feet a day gross until Tamar comes online. Overall, it was a quarter of exceptional operational performance in Israel, meeting record gas demand reliably, bringing two new wells online and continuing our outstanding safety performance.
Once the said coach press rig completes our exploration test at Leviathan, we will begin development drilling at Tamar. Leviathan is now drilling, and we anticipate seeing results by the end of the year. Again, this is a 16 trillion cubic foot gross prospect with a 50% chance of success. Chuck mentioned that we will bring a second rig to the region early next year. Depending on results from the Leviathan well, I would expect that we will drill between two and four exploration or appraisal wells in the area in 2011 as we continue to test the potential of this under-explored basin. We have recently completed additional 3D seismic acquisition offshore Israel adding another 925 square miles of coverage.
Turning to our total company sales outlook for the fourth quarter, volumes should range between 212,000 to 222,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Combined with strong sales year-to-date, our full year average outlook has increased into the upper half of our previous guidance or 214,000 to 217,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
In the U.S., the fourth quarter will not include any volumes from the 6,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day divestiture that closed in August. Compared to the third quarter, natural gas sales volumes in Israel will be down due to the seasonality and the North Sea and deepwater Gulf of Mexico volumes will see some decline. We expect our Central DJ Basin volumes will continue to show growth and oil volumes in Equatorial Guinea should be higher as the third quarter was an underlifted period.
Our activity level remains high as we rapidly approach 2011. We will continue to gather more information on the horizontal Niobrara program.  Weâ€™ll prepare for our return to drilling in the Gulf of Mexico. Internationally, we're focused on keeping both Aseng and Alen moving in West Africa and Tamar in Israel. We should have results from Leviathan by the end of the year. That's a quick look at our key activities. So Holly, I think now we're ready to open it up for questions.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Couple of questions both on the Niobrara, can you add a bit more color on the two wells that you drilled with seismic outside Wattenberg, without natural fractures I know it's early but any read across from these results regarding the potential efficacy of that matrix flow outside of Wattenberg?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Really not a whole lot to add at this time, Brian. As you said, we drilled two there now. We drilled them in what we would have designate as quiet areas, very little fracturing expectation. We saw nice initial rates that 500 to 600 barrels a day as we bro
componenttext: Really not a whole lot to add at this time, Brian. As you said, we drilled two there now. We drilled them in what we would have designate as quiet areas, very little fracturing expectation. We saw nice initial rates that 500 to 600 barrels a day as we brought them on, and we're still just a couple of months into that. And we just have to get some more time to see how they produce. The main thing up here, you remember compared to -- in Wattenberg they have much less gas production and GOR is probably closer to around 1,000 in this area. So we just got to give them some time to produce. But we're encouraged with what we've seen so far. And as we mentioned, we're stepping out now and going to test some areas that look like has a little more faulting expectation and a little more fracturing, and we're just starting to clean those wells up and then we'll have a chance to compare those over the next couple of months.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, I think you'd mentioned in your comments that you're seeing some areas work to a greater degree using vertical wells that you didn't think where it worked before. I believe that your analyst is bending you to talk about almost double t
componenttext: And as a follow-up, I think you'd mentioned in your comments that you're seeing some areas work to a greater degree using vertical wells that you didn't think where it worked before. I believe that your analyst is bending you to talk about almost double the IRR, the rate of return from drilling horizontally versus Codell and Niobrara vertical well. And I guess I was wondering if that is changing a little bit where the vertical wells are, are you seeing better returns from vertical drilling and what's driving that?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me just clarify that a little, Brian. What I was mentioning was in some of the areas where vertical wells are maybe a little more marginal like up in the north and to the east. We're actually seeing some nice horizontal results and what I was rea
componenttext: Yes, let me just clarify that a little, Brian. What I was mentioning was in some of the areas where vertical wells are maybe a little more marginal like up in the north and to the east. We're actually seeing some nice horizontal results and what I was really trying to get across is the horizontal results are opening up some areas that maybe weren't as attractive vertically.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: The bottom line there that is we're taking something that basically was, in our view, almost non-economic and turning it into a very good return. So the uplift is really positive there.

componenttext: Driven by the horizontal activity in those areas.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, we're wrapping up our budget work, so we don't have it finalized. But I think one thing that you can tie off from is the drilling activity, which we noted we expected to be basically double what we're doing in this year, certainly from a well count
componenttext: Again, we're wrapping up our budget work, so we don't have it finalized. But I think one thing that you can tie off from is the drilling activity, which we noted we expected to be basically double what we're doing in this year, certainly from a well count standpoint. So that will drive additional capital into the DJ Basin and so, that is our plan right now. We expect to maintain a very strong legacy program in Wattenberg. So we're not robbing that. This is -- I think it's safe to say, it's very much an incremental program. But we're still working on the parts of the basin that we'll go into. We're obviously going to be working in all the areas that we outlined and we'll get that finalized. But it will be a substantial program.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, Dave, just to that same extent, what you'll see next year probably is -- from compared to this year, we'll be moving some of what was lease acquisition capital this year up in that basin into drilling capital next year.
componenttext: Yes, I guess, Dave, just to that same extent, what you'll see next year probably is -- from compared to this year, we'll be moving some of what was lease acquisition capital this year up in that basin into drilling capital next year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up, moving to the Gulf of Mexico for a second, you mentioned on the call that you thought that you might see some drilling activity by year end. Can you kind of maybe differentiate whether that would be appraisal drilling, whether you think we
componenttext: As a follow-up, moving to the Gulf of Mexico for a second, you mentioned on the call that you thought that you might see some drilling activity by year end. Can you kind of maybe differentiate whether that would be appraisal drilling, whether you think we'll actually start to see true exploration drilling again? And maybe just a little bit more color on the outlook there especially how it relates to what kind of timing that looks like and then also what that means with respect to expenses in terms of cost to drill and work through programs.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, the operative word is hope. I hope that we'll see something by the end of the year. And the only reason I say that is as Dave pointed out, we have submitted the applications to resume work on two wells we were drilling at the time of the morat
componenttext: Sure. Well, the operative word is hope. I hope that we'll see something by the end of the year. And the only reason I say that is as Dave pointed out, we have submitted the applications to resume work on two wells we were drilling at the time of the moratorium, that was Santiago and Deep Blue. So certainly, we would expect that those -- whenever we receive approval, it will be one of those that will likely get early approval. And as I noted, I was hopeful that those and perhaps Gunflint might be early in the queue because we were drilling into known reservoirs, ones that had been penetrated before.  And so in our view, it's more likely that those types of operations might get earlier approval than pure rank exploration. I only say that because some of the experience that other companies had when they were resuming operations in the shallow water that those that were more known and viewed to be, they could be easily looked through when you had known pore pressures and regimes and drilling programs that they be might bubble up as early approvals. When that will happen -- I'm only speculating because that review process started. Again I noted, we do have a positive, these are being permitted on the ENSCO rig that is actually been working during the moratorium. It was very early certified. And so we've got what we believe is a working certified rig, so that part of it we can work through. There's still more things that have to be done. And clearly, our experience in getting the Galapagos completion permits was that they had a lot of work and a lot of iterations to go through. So I would not expect anything to be just a send in and it comes back approved. I would think that there will be some iterations in these drilling permits. So if anything happens, I would say it's going to have very little cost impact on this year. Our view is that all of this will be part of our 2011 plans and weâ€™ve certainly got flexibility to accommodate the schedule, whatever turns out.

componenttext: I think the uncertainty is as you start to move north of Wattenberg as you get into the Northern Colorado and Southern Wyoming areas, and I think the question there is that all of us are looking at and trying to understand is what is the contribution for matrix versus fractures and how dependent one versus the other in those areas. And that's where we're still really early in this game of trying to understand and help in defining what are the areas that are really going to be economically attractive as we go up through the north of this play.

componenttextpreview: Not to a large extent. I think what I'm saying is we're integrating that with our EG. But we have now a more regional picture. I think what I alluded to is we're looking at prospects of a fairly large size over 100 million barrels or greater. And we're se
componenttext: Not to a large extent. I think what I'm saying is we're integrating that with our EG. But we have now a more regional picture. I think what I alluded to is we're looking at prospects of a fairly large size over 100 million barrels or greater. And we're seeing a few prospects bubble up there and that's what we're starting to get ready in the queue and sort through as to which ones we'll be drilling. I think we'll have some -- I would expect we'll have some activity in Cameroon next year. And then that will give us a chance to compare some additional oil exploration in that area along with what we've already seen over on the EG [Equatorial Guinea] side. So we'll start to get a much larger regional picture over there. If you remember, we got over 1 million acres over there and very little of it has been explored down here into the Miocene or below.

componenttext: Well, if you look at it, it takes two to three weeks to drill a well. And then to complete them, it will get completed over the next month or so. So I'd say at any point in time, with two to three rigs running, we'll have a backlog running into the end of the year, four to six wells maybe. And that kind of how it flows through. I'd say when you look at 2011, by the end of 2011, you're looking at the same type of thing where you have probably a monthâ€™s worth of drilling that you're still waiting to complete at any point in time.

componenttext: The difficulty of course up here is still trying to flow back a well that's been completed if you got just a high, high fluid volumes and so trying to design a system that can accommodate flow back and then go into the true more normal production is quite a bit optimization work that needs to be done on that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's a couple of things and it's not all driven by geology. Some -- in our own minds, some has to do with the infrastructure availability, where once you get up into Wyoming, it really starts to disappear on you. And so, your pace of work is somewhat l
componenttext: There's a couple of things and it's not all driven by geology. Some -- in our own minds, some has to do with the infrastructure availability, where once you get up into Wyoming, it really starts to disappear on you. And so, your pace of work is somewhat limited by accommodating and building out infrastructure. So one of the things that is probably affecting our scale of program in 2011 the most is just making sure that we have infrastructure to be able to continue to test and produce wells. So that's probably one of the primary things. Those two areas are both well away from Wattenberg so they're not influenced by the Wattenberg geology. But they do have differences in infrastructure. We've got in the Grover area, we had some existing ongoing development there. We've got some ability to handle production better. And so, we did focus some of our work there. So that I think is one of the primary drivers on those two areas.
